A whole four days of live womenâ€™s racing at the Lotto Belgium Tour later and here we are: on the eve of La Course. The excitement of the LBT served as the perfect warm up event for the warm up event but the race was exciting, and dramatic, and brilliant in its own right â€” not merely an amuse-bouche to the latest round of the WWT. This looks to be the last La Course so lap up the live coverage (if youâ€™re an early bird) and, local elections be damned, weâ€™re sure to be in for an exciting race.

Oh, and the elephant in the room: the Bracke case. Lots has already been said on this subject but I think we can all agree on two points: 1) three years isnâ€™t enough and 2) it took far too long. The Freewheeling podcast and the many articles on the subject will give you more detail that I am willing to go into here because Iâ€™ll still be typing next week â€” and that wonâ€™t do, because by then it will be the first stage of the Giro Rosa (ok, â€˜Giro dâ€™Italia Donne.â€™)Â 

On the subject of the Giroâ€¦ I canâ€™t lie, itâ€™s crept up on me. Suddenly, itâ€™s one week away. Where did June go? What day is it? If I can scrape my brain from off the floor Iâ€™ll do my best to pull out some bonus content and analysis, stay tuned.

NewsÂ ğŸ“°

  • Doltcini-Van Eyck manager and director Marc Bracke has been suspended for three years by the UCI Disciplinary Commission for sexual harassment. Amongst other entirely inappropriate actions for a team manager, Bracke was found to have asked former ridersÂ Sara YoumansÂ andÂ Marion SicotÂ for photos of themselves in their â€œpanties and braâ€Â and â€œbikini.â€Â Astonishingly, the team released a statement defending Bracke and outlining his intent to appeal. More detailsÂ here.Â

Lotto Belgium Tour 2.1Â 

  • Prologue â€“ It was one for the comeback kids.Â Ellen van DijkÂ took her first win since recovering from Covid-19, and her teammateÂ Elynor BackstedtÂ took second after breaking her leg in 2020.Â 
  • Stage one â€“Â Lorena WiebesÂ won the bunch sprint ahead of an impressively consistentÂ Jolien Dâ€™Hoore,Â Barbara GuarischiÂ took third, and Dâ€™Hoore moved into the leaderâ€™s jersey.
  • Stage twoÂ Alena AmialiusikÂ took a solo, rare victory withÂ Lorena WiebesÂ out-sprintingÂ Lotte KopeckyÂ for second and nabbing the GC lead. Kopecky moved up to second with a two-second deficit.Â 
  • Stage three â€“ On todayâ€™s final stage, Kopecky went solo on the Muur van Geraardsbergen after Wiebes was involved in a crash late in the stage. An impressive ride sawÂ Yara KastelijnÂ take second and van Dijk third. Kopeckyâ€™s dominant climbing and Wiebesâ€™s bad luck saw the Belgian take the overall win by 20 seconds ahead of van Dijk with Wiebes third at 36 seconds.

If you missed any of the action you can replay it on GCN+ .

Upcoming RacesÂ ğŸ“…

Set your alarms early, itâ€™s time for everyoneâ€™s favourite sideshow:Â La Course!

At the unsociable hour of 8:20am CEST tomorrow, the womenâ€™s peloton will race their first World Tour event sinceÂ Vuelta a Burgos FÃ©minas. The (possibly?) last ever La Course has been shuffled forward a day (those all-important local elections, remember?) and â€” thus far â€” shuffled off the calendar for 2022 making way for the eight-day Tour de France Femmes. Starting in Brest and finishing in Landerneau the 108km course incorporates four ascents of the CÃ´te de la Fosse aux Loups and if last yearâ€™s racing is anything to go by it will be ğŸ”¥.
